questions.text: A 22-year-old female with newly diagnosed Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus is struggling to maintain postprandial glucose levels despite basal-bolus insulin therapy. Her endocrinologist decides to add an adjunctive medication approved for both type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following drugs fits this indication?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option C: Pramlintide

  • Pramlintide is an amylin analog, approved for use in both type 1 and type 2 diabetes mellitus, in patients already on insulin.

  • It slows gastric emptying, suppresses postprandial glucagon, and promotes satiety, helping improve postprandial glucose control.

  • Empagliflozin (SGLT2 inhibitor) is used only in type 2 DM, not type 1 due to DKA risk. Linagliptin is a DPP-4 i 

  • Semagutide is not approved for use in type 1 DM as it needs some beta cell reserve to be able to produce insulin by incretin effect

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with fever, facial pain, and a black necrotic eschar on her nasal turbinates. A CT scan shows sinus involvement and extension to the brain. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

choices.text: Immediate surgical debridement and intravenous amphotericin B

questions.solution:
Answer is Option B: Immediate surgical debridement and intravenous amphotericin B

  • In cases of rhino-cerebral mucormycosis, especially with signs of significant tissue necrosis and possible central nervous system involvement, immediate surgical debridement is essential to remove necrotic tissue and control the infection.
  • Intravenous amphotericin B is the first-line antifungal treatment that targets the causative organisms, significantly improving the patient's chances of survival.

 

Infections in Diabetes Mellitus

  • Diabetes mellitus (DM) increases susceptibility to opportunistic infections.
  • Focused infections:
    • Rhino-cerebral mucormycosis (RCM)
    • Acute emphysematous cholecystitis
    • Pyelonephritis

Rhino-Cerebral Mucormycosis (RCM)

Aspect

Details

Overview

Severe fungal infection affecting nasal passages, sinuses, and brain.

Causative Agent

Primarily caused by Rhizopus oryzae, associated with uncontrolled DM and diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA).

Pathophysiology

Begins in nasal turbinates; progresses rapidly due to angioinvasive nature, causing tissue necrosis and vascular thrombosis.

Clinical Manifestations

Fever, facial pain, swelling, nasal discharge, necrotic eschar.

Diagnosis

Imaging studies and histopathological examination.

Treatment

Immediate antifungal therapy (e.g., amphotericin B) and aggressive surgical debridement.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes presents for a routine eye examination with compliants of visual loss. On examination, she is found to have microaneurysms, retinal haemorrhages, cotton wool spots and macular edema. What is the most effective management option for her symptomatic foveal oedema?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Intravitreal anti-VEGF injections

  • The patient likely has diabetic macular oedema, a complication of diabetic retinopathy characterized by retinal thickening and fluid accumulation in the macula. This condition can lead to visual impairment and requires prompt treatment to preserve vision.
  • Anti-VEGF therapy has been shown to be more effective than laser treatment for symptomatic foveal oedema in diabetic macular oedema.

 

Diabetic Retinopathy

  • Severity increases with the duration of diabetes. 
  • Ischemia-induced VEGF production and capillary dropout may originate from or involve the area around the inner nuclear layer (especially the deep capillary plexus)
  • The actual proliferation of new vessels (neovascularization) that we clinically detect in PDR happens on the surface of the retina — at the inner limiting membrane (ILM) and into the vitreous.

 

Management:

  • Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy:
    • Untreated can lead to vitreous haemorrhage and retinal detachment.
    • Pan-retinal Laser Photocoagulation: Preserves vision if applied early.
  • Diabetic Macular Oedema:
    • Intravitreal injection therapy is now preferred 
    • Anti-VEGF injections are more effective than laser treatment, often requiring monthly injections.

 

Pan-retinal laser photocoagulation (Option A): While effective for proliferative diabetic retinopathy, it is not the first-line treatment for symptomatic foveal oedema.

 

Corticosteroid injections (Option C): While they may have some benefit, anti-VEGF injections are typically preferred in current clinical practice for treating diabetic macular oedema.

 

Routine observation and follow-up (Option D): This option is not appropriate for symptomatic foveal oedema, as timely intervention is necessary to prevent vision loss.

questions.text: Best screening test for evaluation of diabetic nephropathy is
questions.solution:
Answer is D: Urinary protein to creatinine ratio

Serum creatinine and creatinine clearance rise only after significant nephron loss (≥50%), so they miss early kidney damage like microalbuminuria.
They are late markers and poor indicators for early diabetic nephropathy screening.

Diabetic nephropathy begins with microalbuminuria (30–300 mg/day). uPCR can detect even small increases in albumin accurately.

Most important is that it is a quantitative test and not qualitative test. By using creatinine as a reference, uPCR corrects for variations in urine concentration.

It requires only a random spot urine sample, not cumbersome 24-hour urine collection. Improves patient compliance. 

More consistent and less expensive than repeated 24h urine collections. Useful for routine diabetic follow-up

questions.text: All of the following are correct about diabetic neuropathy except?

choices.text: Third nerve palsy presents with pupillary involvement
Orthostatic hypotension occurs due to involvement of type B fibers
Clonidine is used for management of diabetic diarrhea

questions.solution:
Answer is B: Third nerve palsy presents with pupillary involvement

Most common cranial nerve affected in DM is occulomotor nerve with pupillary sparing. 

Microvascular ischemia affects the central core of the nerve where the somatic motor fibers are located. Thus EOM palsy will occur causing ptosis and eye being down and out. 

Peripheral parasympathetic fibers are spared because they are supplied by pial blood vessels on the nerve’s surface.

Other options 

A:  Diabetic neuropathy affects unmyelinated type C fibers, causing burning pain and autonomic symptoms because these fibers are most vulnerable to chronic hyperglycemia-induced oxidative stress.
C:  Orthostatic hypotension arises from damage to lightly myelinated type B preganglionic fibers, as ischemia impairs sympathetic vasoconstriction needed to maintain BP upon standing.
D:  Clonidine, an α2-agonist, helps in diabetic diarrhea by reducing intestinal secretions through inhibition of sympathetic outflow to the gut.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about Type 2 diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is D: Increased PPAR-γ activity

Increased PPAR-γ activity helps treat diabetes and does not cause it.  

Activation of PPAR-γ improves:

  1. Insulin sensitivity (especially in adipose and muscle tissue)

  2. Glucose uptake via GLUT4

  3. Storage of lipids in adipose tissue

In Type 2 DM in early stages , insulin levels are elevated. In late stage beta cell exhaustion occurs causing insulinopenia. That is why in late phase of type 2 DM insulin is needed and OHA donot work. 

Type 2DM has polygenic patten of inheritance

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about mechanism of action of Acarbose?

choices.text: Increases insulin secretion from pancreatic beta cells
Inhibits α-glucosidase in intestinal brush border
Increases glucose uptake in peripheral tissues
Enhances insulin sensitivity in peripheral tissues

questions.solution:
Answer is B: Inhibits α-glucosidase in intestinal brush border

-Acarbose inhibits alpha-glucosidase enzymes in the gut, slowing the digestion of carbohydrates and reducing post-meal glucose spikes.

-It is taken with each meal to reduce post-prandial blood glucose and modestly improve glycemic control.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about complications seen in Diabetes mellitus?

choices.text: Blindness incidence is increased by 25 times
Foot gangrene and amputation risk is increased by 100 times
Most common site of diabetic foot ulcer is heel
Diabetic nephropathy is leading cause of Chronic kidney disease

questions.solution:
Option is C: Most common site of diabetic foot ulcer is heel

Diabetic foot ulcer is usually seen on toes or metatarsal heads.

Risk of blindness in diabetics is upto 25 times higher as compared to normal population due to neovascularization. It can lead to retinal detachment and vitreous hemorrhage. 

Diabetic nephropathy leads to diffuse glomerulosclerosis that casues progressive decline of eGFR. At values less < 30 ml /min , either Hemodialysis or kidney transplanatation decision making has to be done. 

Due to combination of neuropathy and angiopathy, risk of critical limb ischemia, non-healing ulcers, and ultimately digital gangrene or limb amputation is much higher reaching upto 40-100 x times more than normal population.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about SGLT2i

choices.text: Used in HFreEF in non diabetic population
Increased risk of mycotic genital infections

questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Cause afferent arteriolar dilatation 

-SGLT2i will cause salt loss in urine. It will increase sodium at macula densa and cause afferent constriction. This reduces intraglomerular pressure. Thus it reduces progression of diabetic nephropathy 

-Salt loss in urine also lowers SBP by 5 mm Hg and explains the cardiovascular benefit without causing orthostatic hypotension 

-Increased sugar levels in urine explains the risk of mycotic genital infections and UTI.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest renal abnormality in diabetic nephropathy?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Increased glomerular filtration rate 

  • The earliest functional change in diabetic nephropathy is glomerular hyperfiltration, seen as an increased GFR due to afferent arteriolar dilation resulting from altered tubuloglomerular feedback. 

  • This precedes microalbuminuria, which marks the first clinical stage.

  • Structural changes like Kimmelstiel–Wilson nodules occur much later.

questions.text: 50-year-old man with T2DM presents with consistently elevated early morning blood glucose levels. His continous glucose monitoring does not show any noctural hypoglycemia.  His current insulin regimen includes twice-daily intermediate-acting insulin. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for his fasting hyperglycaemia?

choices.text: Excess dose of insulin given the day before
Increased insulin sensitivity between 4 am to 8 am
Inreased insulin resistance between 4 am to 8 am

questions.solution:
Answer is C: Increased insulin resistance between 4 am and 8 am 

 

The patient has dawn phenomenon, where early morning hyperglycemia results from increased insulin resistance between 4 am to 8 am. The lack of preceding nocturnal hypoglycemia rules out somogyi phenomenon.

Somogyi phenomenon: Hormones involved are catecholamines, cortisol, glucagon and GH

Dawn phenomenon : Hormones involved are cortisol and GH

 

Dawn Phenomenon vs Somogyi Phenomenon:

Feature

Dawn Phenomenon

Somogyi Phenomenon

Definition

Fasting hyperglycaemia in the early morning due to natural circadian hormone resistance 

Rebound hyperglycemia after nocturnal hypoglycemia due to counterregulatory hormone release. 


Horomones involved 

Increased release of growth hormone and cortisol in the late night hours.

Glucagon, catecholamines and cortisol due to body's response to late-night hypoglycaemia. 

Timing

Happens between 4 am to 8 am  due to circadian rhythms and insufficient insulin.

Occurs after midnight, following hypoglycaemia, leading to elevated morning blood glucose levels.

Clinical Relevance

Requires adjusting insulin doses and timing to prevent early morning hyperglycemia.

Early morning hyperglycemia was once thought to be due to prior hypoglycaemia, but new research questions this theory.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs slows the progression of diabetic nephropathy and is an aldosterone antagonist?
questions.solution:
Answer is A : Finrenone 

Drugs that slow the progression of CKD in diabetic nephropathy 

  1. ACEi or ARB 
  2. Finrenone 
  3. SGLT2i - Empagliflozin
  4. GLP1RA

Drugs to avoid in diabetic nephropathy 

  1. NSAIDS
  2. Metformin 
  3. Dual RAAS blockade with ACEi and ARB

questions.text: A 52-year-old obese male with poorly controlled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus is started on semaglutide. Which of the following statements is not true regarding this drug?

choices.text: It acts via GLP-1 receptor agonism, enhancing glucose-dependent insulin secretion
It may cause abdominal pain and elevated serum amylase levels suggestive of pancreatitis
It can cause transient worsening of diabetic retinopathy, especially in patients with rapid glycemic improvement
It commonly causes fluid retention and weight gain due to PPAR-γ activation

questions.solution:
Answer is D: It commonly causes fluid retention and weight gain due to PPAR-γ activation

A – True: Semaglutide is a GLP-1 receptor agonist, increases insulin release in a glucose-dependent manner.

B – True: Semaglutide is associated with pancreatitis; patients may show raised amylase/lipase.

C – True: Rapid correction of chronic hyperglycemia by semaglutide and even intensive insulin therapy causes sudden shift in retinal perfusion , altered retinal blood flow and endothelial function causing transient worsening of pre-existing microvascular damage. 

D – false (Correct answer): Fluid retention and weight gain are side effects of thiazolidinediones like pioglitazone which act via PPAR-γ – not seen with semaglutide.

Extra mile 

Semaglutide carries a black box warning for Risk of thyroid C-cell tumors, including medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) based on studies on rodents. So contraindicated in patients with MEN 2

questions.text:
50-year-old female with Type 2 diabetes mellitus comes for consultation due to extreme fatigue and thirst. BP 170/100 mm Hg . She is non compliant on her medicines and latest labs are mentioned below. Which is not correct about management of this case? 


	Random Plasma Glucose: 286 mg/dl
	HbA1c: 11.2 %
	Urine glucose +++
	Serum creatinine 2 mg/dl 
	eGFR: 25 mL/min
	Serum potassium 6.5 meq /dl
questions.solution:
Answer is B: Start Metformin with Sitagliptin

The patient has developed diabetic nephropathy and eGFR of 25 implies grade 4 CKD. 

Metformin is contraindicated in patients with significant renal impairment (eGFR < 30 mL/min) due to the increased risk of lactic acidosis.Sitagliptin is metabolized by kidney. Control of hyperrtension with CCB is required as serum potassium is elevated. ACEi are not be given with high potassium values. Empagliflozin is indicated as eGFR is less than 30 ml /min and it shows cardio renal benefit by lowering SBP.

questions.text: You are educating a mother of  8-year-old girl with type 1 Diabetes Mellitus about insulin administration techniques. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding insulin delivery?

choices.text: The preferred site for subcutaneous insulin injection is the anterior abdominal wall.
Insulin pens should be held at a 90° angle to the skin for optimal delivery
Repeated insulin injections at the same site can cause lipohypertrophy
Repeat the insulin injection spot after 5-7 days

questions.solution:
Correct answer is D: Repeat the insulin injection site after 5-7 days

Repeating the same injection spot should be avoided for at least 2 weeks to allow tissue healing and reduce lipodystrophy risk. 

Repeated use of same site may cause lipodystrophy . Lipohypertrophy is more common and is seen due to anabolic effects of insulin. 

The anterior abdominal wall is the preferred site due to consistent absorption.

90° angle ensures proper SC delivery using insulin pens or syringes.

questions.text: 60 year old diabetic patient collapsed in the bathroom in the morning and died.  She was on metformin and glipizide for last 10 years. Her latest HbA1c was 11%. What can be possible cause of this event?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Autonomic neuropathy 

Uncontrolled diabetes with 10-year duration  will have increased risk of cardiac autonomic neuropathy. 

It can cause silent myocardial ischemia, arrhythmias, nocturnal bradycardia, or QT prolongation, leading to sudden death, especially overnight or early morning (bathroom collapse is classic).

HbA1c : 11%  indicates suboptimal control, further increasing microvascular and autonomic complications.

Congestive chronic heart failure causes gradual decompensation, not sudden collapse unless massive arrhythmia.

CNS bleed would present with headache, focal neuro deficits, and may not cause instant death unless massive

There is no history suggestive of cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with T2DM is brought to ER in unconcious state. Work up shows ABG pH=7.38, pCO2 40 mm Hg HCO3 = 26 meq/L, Sodium 140 meq/L , K =5.5 meq/L urine ketostix is negative, RBS : 150 mg/dl and serum lactate is normal. Which of the following is correct about next step in managment of this patient?

choices.text: Normal saline followed by insulin drip
Draw blood culture and start empirical antimicrobials

questions.solution:
Answer is option A: NCCT head 

Presentation given is of a diabetic patient with normal glucose, no acidosis, no ketones, and normal lactate, the most likely cause of sudden unconsciousness should trigger an evaluation for neurological causes (e.g., stroke or seizure).

Based on lab reports hypoglycemia, DKA, hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state and sepsis are ruled out. Hence we will perform NCCT head to evaluate for CNS event like stroke.

questions.text: Which of the following drug will worsen cardiovascular mortality in a diabetic patient who underwent a CABG?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Rosiglitazone 

Rosiglitazone, a thiazolidinedione , has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular events, particularly myocardial infarction and heart failure, especially in patients with existing cardiovascular disease or those who have undergone procedures like CABG. 

Antidiabetic drugs proven to reduce cardiovascular mortality in T2DM:

  1. SGLT2 inhibitors

    • Empagliflozin, Canagliflozin, Dapagliflozin

    • Proven to reduce CV death, hospitalization for heart failure, and renal outcomes

    • Especially useful in T2DM with HF or CKD

  2. GLP-1 receptor agonists

    • Semaglutide, Liraglutide, Dulaglutide

    • Reduce major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE) in atherosclerotic CV disease

  3. Tirzepatide

    • A dual GLP-1 + GIP agonist

questions.text: Which form of insulin is used for basal delivery in basal bolus regimen?
questions.solution:
Answer is C: Glargine 

Glargine serves the basal role to maintain background insulin levels. Glulisine and Lispro serves as bolus role in insulin regimen to control the post prandial spikes. Bolus insulin is given 3 times per day. 

Glargine is a long-acting basal insulin designed to provide steady insulin levels throughout the day, with an onset of action around 1–2 hours and a duration of approximately 24 hours.

In contrast, Lispro is a rapid-acting bolus insulin, primarily used to control postprandial glucose spikes. It begins to act within about 15 minutes of injection and lasts for 3–5 hours.

NPH (Neutral Protamine Hagedorn) is an intermediate-acting insulin, with a slower onset (2–4 hours) and peak effect around 6–8 hours, often given twice daily.

 

Typical Dosing Strategy of basal bolus: dose ~0.5 units/kg/day

  • 50% as basal

  • 50% divided as bolus before meals
